We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the evolution of cognitive ability. We also show that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is not only determined by the evolution of brain size but also by the evolution of the number of neurons in the brain. This study provides a more complete picture of the evolution of brain information-processing capacity. It also provides a more complete picture of the evolution of animal cognition. This study has implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

TRAP1 is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells and suggests that TRAP1 may be a potential therapeutic target in cancer. (truncated)

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, the mechanism by which ADF/cofilin severes filaments is unknown. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin binds to filaments more efficiently in regions of high curvature, but severing is favored in regions of low curvature. We also find that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon ADF/cofilin binding. We propose that this torque dramatically enhances severing. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for how ADF/cofilin can sever highly connected filament networks. This mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for understanding severing in general, and for understanding the role of ADF/cofilin in severing in particular.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in place of glucose in processed foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and diabetes.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, with a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. The recent history of Madagascar is also revealed by the genomic data, showing that the settlement of Madagascar was not a single event but rather a series of independent colonizations. In addition, we show that a few centuries are enough to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is common, and some of these modifications can have important functional consequences. In this study, we show that the presence of one common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the reconstituted translation system as well as human cells. These findings highlight the potential for chemical modifications to have subtle effects on the translation of mRNAs. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of health and behavioral outcomes, including better social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to the inclusion of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, or to the measurement of worthwhile ratings over a 4-y period. The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal clades. The aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes by constraining the size of the aquatic realm.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (truncated)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense the presence of surfaces. This mechanosensory system is essential for the persistence of the bacterium in the environment and in the host, and is required for the regulation of a wide range of virulence factors. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of mechanosensory systems in bacteria and the regulation of virulence in pathogenic bacteria. They also have implications for the development of new strategies for the control of bacterial infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. This has led to an increase in pesticide contamination of surface waters, which is a major threat to aquatic biodiversity. The current study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide contamination of surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is a major step forward in the understanding of the global pesticide contamination of surface waters. It will help to inform the development of effective policies to protect aquatic biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the ecology of emerging infectious diseases. Here we report the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in the United States. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and suggest that a “One Health” approach is needed to monitor the ecology of emerging infectious diseases. This study highlights the need for a better understanding of the ecology of emerging infectious diseases.

The hydropower industry has been building dams in the developing world for decades. The proliferation of large dams in the Mekong River Basin, the Amazon River Basin, and the Congo River Basin is a global concern. This paper examines the problems associated with building large dams in developing countries and the need to incorporate climate change into the decision-making process. We also discuss the importance of incorporating the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. Although the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is well established, the contribution of other molecules, such as cytokines, to the disease process is less clear. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type responsible for Aβ production, are also the primary source of cytokines that are involved in the initiation of the AD-related immune response. Our findings suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis. This study provides insight into the mechanisms that may be involved in the initiation of the AD-related immune response and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the study of the evolution of animal husbandry. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens was practiced at that site as early as the fourth century B.C.E. We further show that the frequency of chicken in the Southern Levant increased sharply during the Hellenistic period, and that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe predates the earliest evidence from the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides new insights into the evolution of animal husbandry in the ancient world. (Less)

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that has been studied extensively. We find that the folding of the protein is a multistep process. The folding intermediates are native-like and are formed in distinct steps. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. This list is growing, and it is becoming clear that the folding of proteins is a complex process that is not yet understood. (Show more)

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular mechanisms that control the concentration of Np4 and the rate at which it is degraded remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to degrade triphosphorylated RNA, also has the ability to remove dinucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) from the 5′ end of capped RNA. This enzyme has a unique mechanism for recognizing capped RNA 5′ termini, which results in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of immunosuppression. This study shows that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is a key player in the immune dysfunction observed in sepsis. We demonstrate that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The results of these studies could lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. This work is a step toward a global census of the biomass of all taxa on the planet. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against pathogens is well established. However, the role of immune peptides in the defense of plants against pests is less clear. Here, we show that a structurally unique immune peptide from a model legume, Medicago truncatula, exhibits potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The peptide binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and induces reactive oxygen species in germlings of the fungal pathogen. The peptide also exhibits potent fungicidal activity against plant fungal pathogens when applied as a spray. Our work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique immune peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work also highlights the potential of immune peptides as a new class of fungicides. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the sperm proteome, and that these contributions are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that associate with humans, is only now being explored. This study is a first step in this exploration, and it provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome. The study also provides a proof of principle for the power of metagenomics to study the human virome, and it demonstrates the potential of metagenomics to study the human microbiome in general.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been the subject of much debate. The most recent estimate of the temperature of the surface of the Earth is 15 °C. This estimate is based on the isotopic composition of marine cherts. However, this estimate has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present a method for determining the temperature of the Earth’s surface based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that the temperature of the Earth’s surface has decreased over geological time. This finding is consistent with previous estimates based on isotopic data and provides new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. This work is an example of the power of integrative science to provide new insights into the history of our planet. (Show more)

K+ channels are the most abundant ion channels in the body and are involved in a wide variety of physiological and pathological processes. The K+ channel KCNK15, also known as the BK channel, is a large-conductance calcium-activated potassium channel that is involved in the regulation of heart rate and vascular tone. The BK channel is unique in that it does not have an intracellular activation gate and does not show C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings provide insights into the regulation of K+ channel gating and inactivation. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and initiate disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would suggest that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and could lead to the development of new strategies to combat the disease. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects, and it is difficult to tune its properties. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain, and that the bandgap can be tuned by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings also provide a platform for machine learning of the electronic and phonon structures of diamond. This work is expected to advance the understanding of the mechanical properties of diamond, and to promote its applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza virus disease. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how this merge operation is implemented in the brain is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s response to the words in a sentence varies with each successive word but suddenly when words can be merged into phrases. This response is consistent with a neural implementation of a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This merge operation may be a fundamental step in the brain’s construction of syntactic structures. Understanding this operation is critical for developing models of language processing that can account for the complexity of the underlying structures. (Show more)

Obesity is a major health problem, and the mechanisms that regulate food intake are not fully understood. Here we describe a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating. This circuit is activated by electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus, a region that is also involved in the regulation of feeding. We show that this circuit is involved in the rapid vigorous eating that occurs after stimulation. We also show that this circuit is involved in the overeating that occurs after stimulation of a different brain region. Finally, we show that this circuit is involved in the overeating that occurs after stimulation of a third brain region. Thus, this circuit may contribute to overeating in general.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen in the soil is expected to become increasingly difficult to maintain in the future. Thus, there is a need for sustainable strategies to increase the efficiency of nitrogen acquisition. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be used to develop sustainable agricultural systems that are resilient to the effects of climate change. (Show more)

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are a critical tool for monitoring and preventing deforestation, but they are often too late to deter deforestation. Community-based monitoring programs that combine remote-sensed alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts can reduce deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. The spider’s web is a self-manufactured hearing organ that is much more sensitive than the spider’s body. The spider can hear without a body and can hear without a head.

Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global challenges. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We show that a global phaseout of fossil fuels and a 50% reduction of nonfossil anthropogenic emissions can save 3.61 million people per year from outdoor air pollution and 5.55 million people per year from all anthropogenic sources. This would also reduce global temperature by 0.51 °C and aerosol-perturbed rainfall by 10–70% over densely populated regions in India and 10–30% over Central America, West Africa, and the Sahel. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. Our results highlight the importance of a global approach to address these challenges. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to claim lives and disrupt economies around the world. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the disease, but the global distribution of these vaccines remains a challenge. Here we describe a strategy for the development of a subunit vaccine that can be manufactured at large scale, which may help to address this challenge. The strategy described here is based on a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This work may help to accelerate the development of a vaccine that can be used to address the ongoing pandemic. (Show more)

The ALK receptor tyrosine kinase is involved in the development of many different tissues and is implicated in a variety of human cancers. In the zebrafish, we identified a ligand for human ALK, which is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Here, we show that the three zebrafish ALKALs are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/ALKals in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This is the first report of a ligand–receptor system in a vertebrate. Our findings may help to understand the role of ALK/ALKals in human cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The emergence of plague as a devastating pathogen in humans is one of the most dramatic events in history. The study of ancient plague genomes has provided a unique window into the origins of this pathogen, but the number of genomes available for analysis has been limited. Here, we present 17 ancient plague genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period. Our results provide insights into the evolution of plague during this critical period and reveal a unique pattern of rapid dispersal across continents. These data provide a more complete picture of the formative years of plague and its early evolution. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of agricultural lands is often at odds with SOC storage, as intensive crop production on grassland-derived Mollisols has liberated massive amounts of carbon to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated carbon on these soils. However, the most effective practices are labor intensive and may not be compatible with the needs of the modern agricultural system. Our results highlight the importance of integrating livestock and perennial grasslands into intensive crop production systems to mitigate climate change. This article is protected by copyright. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of zoonotic spillover and spread of novel viruses. We developed a framework to identify risk factors and prioritize viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread to humans. We then created a web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results and to prioritize their own research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to animals that pollinate them. The color of nectar is often an important factor in attracting pollinators, but the mechanisms by which this color is produced are poorly understood. We show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a second alkaloid in the red nectar of Jaltomata herrerae, a hummingbird-visited species, and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergently evolved trait that is likely to be important for attracting pollinators. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–pollinator interaction. (Show more)

We present a study of the genetic structure of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived in the late 5th/early 6th century. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of these women was heterogeneous, and that some of them had a genetic ancestry that was very different from that of modern Europeans. In addition, we show that some of them had a genetic ancestry that was very different from that of modern Europeans. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and may help in the development of strategies to prevent future bat-to-human spillover events

The ability to rapidly identify the pathogen(s) causing undifferentiated fever in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating epidemics. We used metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to identify the pathogen(s) responsible for undifferentiated fever in a periurban population in Cambodia. We found that vector-borne pathogens were the most common clinical category, and that underappreciated zoonotic pathogens were also detected. Early detection of chikungunya virus presaged a larger national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template in eukaryotes. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In S. cerevisiae, the extreme stability of the pol δ holoenzyme ensures that every nucleobase within an Okazaki fragment is faithfully duplicated before dissociation. However, the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme is unknown. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of genetically encoded proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by RNA polymerases. In the laboratory, RNA polymerases have been used to synthesize RNA molecules, but the ability to replicate nucleic acids has not been demonstrated. Here, we show that an RNA polymerase ribozyme can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the in vitro evolution of life.

We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab was evaluated. The results showed that tocilizumab could improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately, and the mortality was reduced. Therefore, tocilizumab is an effective treatment for severe and critical COVID-19 patients. This study provides a reference for the clinical treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess can be toxic. The fungal xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) has been shown to bind copper, but the role of the BGC in copper homeostasis has not been established. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC is involved in copper homeostasis and that the BGC is expressed in the context of a copper-dependent antimicrobial phenotype. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings provide insight into the role of natural products in the evolution of fungal physiology and the evolution of interactions with microbes. (Show more)

Tridymite is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is the first detection of this mineral on another planet. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment suggests that the sediment source for the rock was the crater wall/rim/central peak. The amorphous silica, magnetite, and mixed-cation salts and oxides are diagenesis products derived from multiple aqueous solutions having variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The diagenesis products are consistent with the presence of acidic fluids in the sediment source region and at the site of sediment compaction. The diagenesis products are also consistent with the presence of acidic fluids in the subsurface of Gale crater. Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agriculture, and the frequency of late-spring frosts is expected to increase in the coming decades. However, the geographic distribution of frost risk is poorly understood. We use a large dataset of common garden experiments to infer the frost resistance strategies of woody plants and to forecast the vulnerability of forests to frost damage under climate change. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. Our results also provide a framework for understanding the evolution of frost resistance in plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease is unclear. Here we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which retains an IL-17A+ phenotype and is unable to induce colitis in recipients, whereas the other subset can induce colitis and is dependent on Stat4 and T-bet. These results indicate that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which is required for the development of colitis, and suggest that targeting both subsets may be a more effective approach to treating inflammatory bowel disease. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease mechanism is unknown. Here we report a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes. These cells are highly toxic to motor neurons, suggesting a common mechanism in ALS. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will accelerate ALS research and lead to the development of new therapies. This study also highlights the importance of using living cells for disease modeling and drug screening. This method will also be useful for studying other neurodegenerative diseases. (Read more)

The gut microbiota of ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of pathogens to vertebrate hosts. Here, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the gut microbiota of the vector, the blacklegged tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We demonstrate that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota by altering the composition of the peritrophic matrix, which is a critical barrier for the colonization of pathogens. We also show that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota by altering the composition of the gut microbiota. These data provide insights into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors. This knowledge will be critical for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short tail of modern birds is thought to have evolved from a long tail ending in a compound bone (pygostyle) in the clade Pygostylia. However, the diversity of early members of Pygostylia is limited, and the origin of the short tail is poorly understood. Here, we describe a basal member of Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. Our study increases the known diversity of early members of Pygostylia and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of the avian tail. (Show more)

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the stratosphere in the evolution of our climate. This is a significant contribution to the climate science literature.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are green. The color of a vertebrate can be modified by pigments, such as carotenoids, or by the color of its bones, which are green in many species. This study describes the biochemical and molecular basis of the green color of vertebrates. We show that the green color of vertebrates is due to the presence of a specific class of proteins that bind biliverdin, the pigment that is present in the blood of vertebrates. This study provides a molecular and functional explanation for the green color of vertebrates and for the evolution of the green color in vertebrates. It also provides a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of proteins in the human body. The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. It is also one of the most fragile. The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was easily torn. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and dynamics of extinction and recovery. We present a precise age model for the extinction and recovery based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction and recovery, and the rate-dependent processes controlling the extinction and recovery will be evaluated at millennial timescales. This work provides a critical test of the trigger and kill hypotheses for the extinction. (Show more)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. IBD is a complex disease with multiple causes and mechanisms. The pathogenesis of IBD is still not fully understood. Here, we report that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays a crucial role in the maintenance of intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also demonstrate that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has led to a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the receptor. These results provide insights into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may help to inform the development of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. Our results extend to games with Borel-measurable payoffs in the tail, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and physics. In particular, electronegativity and chemical hardness are two central properties of atoms that can be used to rationalize many chemical phenomena. Here, we show that these properties change with pressure, and we show that the pressure-induced changes in these properties can be used to predict and explain many chemical phenomena. We also show that these properties can be used to predict the formation of unexpected compounds under pressure. Our results provide a new perspective on the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can have important consequences for the global carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of these effects is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between climate, fire, and carbon cycle. We show that changes in human demography can reduce fire activity, which can offset some of the warming caused by emissions. However, climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective under lower emission scenarios. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to consider fire in climate change mitigation strategies.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic relationships. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts only at night, when the squid is producing light. We propose that this strategy may be used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their symbionts. This study highlights the importance of glycans in the regulation of symbiosis. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope that this work will inspire further research on the gendered nature of topics and their relationship to social biases. Our method can be applied to many domains, including social media, news, and literature. We expect that it will be useful to researchers and practitioners in many fields.

The Black Death, the most devastating epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics were the result of repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis provides evidence for the existence of climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This result challenges the traditional view of the Black Death as a singular event and suggests that the disease was the consequence of a series of introductions. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the history of the plague and the spread of infectious diseases in general. (Show more)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web, and their loss can have significant ecological and economic consequences. We report the discovery of a densovirus (Parvoviridae) as the likely cause of a disease that has led to the mass mortality of sea stars (asteroids) on the Pacific coast of North America. The virus was detected in symptomatic and asymptomatic asteroids, suggesting that it is spread by the water. This is the first report of a densovirus causing mass mortality in a marine invertebrate.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic ancestries, with a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals. The settlement history is also complex, with a recent demographic growth and a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous admixture. These results provide a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique case in the world. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of approved vaccines and antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple variants, including Delta. Our results highlight the power of deep learning in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help in the development of new therapeutics to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop expert surveys are a key source of information on crop status, but their value is often overlooked in favor of more sophisticated models. We show that the information contained in crop expert assessments can be used to build a quantitative index of crop condition, which can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop condition index can be used to identify anomalies in crop status, and can be used to predict crop yields with high accuracy. This work provides a framework for the use of crop expert surveys in agricultural monitoring, and can be extended to other crops and countries. It also provides a proof of concept for the use of crowdsourced data in agricultural monitoring.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neural populations. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to integrate information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to integrate information over time. Our results provide a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, limiting our ability to understand the response of soil respiration to climate change. Here, we present the largest global dataset of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, totaling >3,800 observations. Our analysis reveals that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration does not change with experimental warming in most biomes, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our results provide a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. This information is critical to improving our ability to predict the future trajectory of the global carbon cycle. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most challenging to model, as it involves the loss of a major function, photosynthesis, and the acquisition of a new function, the acquisition of nutrients. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis, is the main driver of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This evolutionary trajectory may be relevant to other transitions in the history of life.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was the most severe in the city’s history and highlighted the vulnerability of water supply to climate variability. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 80% under a high-emission scenario by the year 2100. These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is relevant to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, in particular SDG 6, which aims to provide clean water and sanitation to all by 2030. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has been a major advance in the study of materials. The first test explosion of a nuclear bomb, the Trinity test of 16 July 1945, resulted in the fusion of surrounding sand, the test tower, and copper transmission lines into a glassy material known as “trinitite.” Here, we report the discovery, in a sample of red trinitite, of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2. It represents the oldest extant anthropogenic quasicrystal currently known, with the distinctive property that its precise time of creation is indelibly etched in history. Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy into chemical energy that is used by all life. The chlorophyll pigments are the key intermediates in this process. The biosynthesis of these pigments is one of the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth ring of the chlorophyll molecule, the isocyclic ring, is the most important reaction in this pathway. The mechanism of this reaction has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. Here we describe the evolution of the reaction, and the discovery of three classes of the enzyme that catalyzes this reaction. These results provide a framework for understanding the evolution of this important reaction in photosynthesis. (Show more)

Here, we show that ASK1 is involved in neuroinflammation in EAE. We also show that ASK1 is involved in the progression of EAE. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to human activities. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may help in the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1 associated with Stormorken syndrome, a rare disease of hematopoietic and skeletal muscle. Our data suggest that STIM1 p.R304W and ORAI1 p.P245L represent gain-of-function mutations that can be therapeutically targeted to treat Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of CRAC channel dysregulation, and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process. Here we use a model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates spread in a non–cell-autonomous manner, and that this spreading is associated with the death of vulnerable neurons. We also show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on active release and uptake of aggregates. These results provide insight into the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The presence of proteins that are supersaturated in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS suggests that these proteins are prone to aggregation. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The photonic crystal band structures are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants, and the origin of this group is poorly understood. The research presented here focuses on Montsechia, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain in the early 20th century. The morphology and anatomy of Montsechia suggest that it is sister to Ceratophyllum, a group of aquatic plants. Montsechia is the earliest known aquatic angiosperm, and its age raises questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade. This research opens the possibility that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. (Less)

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, and it is often assumed that the evolution of DNA viruses is faster than that of RNA viruses. Here we present the first ancient DNA sequences of B19V, and we show that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought. We also show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred relatively recently. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a new estimate of the acceleration of sea level rise, which is a key parameter in understanding the causes of the acceleration. The acceleration is estimated using a 25-y time series of satellite altimeter data. The acceleration is then used to predict the future rate of sea level rise. The predicted rate of sea level rise is in agreement with the rate predicted by the IPCC AR5 models.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States, but that this increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This pattern is seen across education levels, but is most pronounced for those with less education.

The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity that is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work highlights the power of the integrated application of solid-state NMR, X-ray crystallography, and first-principles computational chemistry to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the disease has a high mortality rate. We tested the efficacy of remdesivir, a nucleotide analog that inhibits viral replication, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Prophylactic treatment with remdesivir prevented disease, and therapeutic treatment reduced virus replication and lung lesions. These results support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial setting, and also suggest that remdesivir may be effective against other coronaviruses. This is the first study to show the efficacy of remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic relationships. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, at a specific time of day. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan-provisioning strategy may be used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their symbiotic microbes. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of symbiosis. (Show more)

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades, and suspensions are associated with long-term negative outcomes for students. This study tested whether teachers could be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. Teachers in three districts (n = 31) were randomized to receive a brief, online intervention that encouraged them to value students’ perspectives and sustain positive relationships while encouraging better behavior. Evaluated at five middle schools, this intervention halved suspension rates from 9.6% to 4.8%. It also bolstered respect the most at-risk students, previously suspended students, perceived from teachers. Teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions and, moreover, can be changed through scalable intervention. This study has implications for the future of school discipline and the future of education.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the function of DNA. The molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. Here, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcriptional fidelity of RNA polymerase II. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions have distinct impact on the transcriptional fidelity of pol II. The minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion is error-free, whereas the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion is error-prone. The N3-EtdT lesion disrupts base pairing and can lead to multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II that is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, precleaved MERS viruses used receptor-proximal, cell-surface proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry, whereas uncleaved MERS viruses trafficked past these cell-surface proteases and into endosomes. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other health problems. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals offered in a catering environment can have a large impact on sales. This suggests that simple changes to catering practices could make a significant contribution to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and improving population health. The results also suggest that it is possible to achieve large changes in behavior without the need for complex interventions. This has implications for the design of interventions to encourage sustainable diets and other health-promoting behaviors. (Show more)

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we use quantitative proteomics to show that the surfaceome is dramatically remodeled in a panel of breast cancer cell lines expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer progression and as a potential therapeutic target. This work also provides a resource for the breast cancer community to identify surface proteins that may be useful as biomarkers and drug targets. In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that is likely to be effective in safeguarding elections in the future.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a global pandemic. The role of accessory proteins in the virus’s biology is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is unique to SARS-CoV-2 and not present in SARS-CoV. The structure reveals a dimerization interface that is unique to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. These results provide insight into the molecular basis of the unique biology of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a trigger of edema in the brain. However, the mechanisms of hypoxia-induced edema are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia triggers edema in the rat brain and that this edema is associated with the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxia-induced edema in the brain. They also suggest that CRFR1 agonists may be useful in the treatment of edema. (Show more)

The scientific enterprise is based on the idea that we can learn from data. This is a powerful idea, but it is not without its challenges. In this paper, we describe a set of challenges that arise when we have a large dataset and we are interested in finding associations in that dataset. We describe some recent developments in statistical theory that address these challenges. These developments are important because they help us to be more careful in our scientific work.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step in the regeneration of organs, such as the liver. However, the generation of vascular networks is difficult to achieve in vitro. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the regeneration of organs. (Show more)

Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are important signaling molecules that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. In addition, RTKs are frequently mutated in human cancer. Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between the RTKs anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) with their ligands. We show that zebrafish deficient in Ltk display a severe defect in iridophore patterning of the eye and the body. These defects are entirely mediated by Ltk and not by Alk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides insights into the physiological function of RTKs and their ligands and may lead to the identification of new therapeutic targets for human disease.
