Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Herein, we provide evidence that STING plays a role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. Specifically, STING deficiency in β-cells and peripheral tissues caused glucose intolerance, suggesting that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin sensitivity. Moreover, STING deficiency in β-cells led to defective GSIS, indicating that STING is required for β-cell function. These findings establish pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These data also provide a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the most important pathogens of humans and animals. They cause annual epidemics and occasional pandemics. The packaging of their genome is a key step in their replication, and the existence of a selective packaging mechanism is suspected. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the packaging of the influenza A virus genome is a sequence-dependent process, and they provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of this process. These results also suggest that the packaging of the influenza A virus genome is a promising target for antiviral drug development. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The atheroprone hemodynamic environment is a critical factor in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Here, we demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by the disturbed flow is a key event in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggests that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of YAP/TAZ in the regulation of vascular homeostasis and the development of atherosclerotic lesions. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a significant threat to human life and property, as well as a major contributor to carbon emissions. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and climate change has likely played a role in the increase in wildfire activity. However, the role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the importance of reducing wildfire risk to people and ecosystems. Actions to reduce wildfire risk should be a focus of United States policy. (Show more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the initial appearance of a neighborhood in determining its future physical improvement. This work is a step toward understanding the physical dynamics of cities and the role of human capital, initial appearance, and urban design in shaping the future of cities.

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insect bites. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides insights into the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of arthropod–plant interaction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune response is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment on the course of the disease. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of the timing of treatment on the course of the disease. Our results can be used to guide the development of treatment strategies for ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that is often used as a proxy for the health of coral reefs. However, the underlying mechanisms are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that separates the host from the external environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky, allowing the spread of cancer cells into the body. Here, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also a barrier to the microbiome. We show that the loss of the BMP signaling pathway leads to the loss of the microbiome, and that the loss of the microbiome leads to the loss of BMP signaling. Our work highlights the importance of maintaining the integrity of the intestinal epithelium to maintain the balance between the host and the microbiome. It also highlights the importance of maintaining the activity of the JNK signaling pathway to maintain the integrity of the intestinal epithelium. This work may help in the development of new therapies for cancer and inflammatory bowel diseases. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Although the majority of breast cancers are hormone receptor–positive, a small percentage of tumors are hormone receptor–negative. These tumors are more aggressive and are more likely to recur after treatment. Chemotherapy is the standard treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy varies widely among patients. Here we show that targeting the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer.

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation is still a matter of debate. Here we show that a unique, ∼192-y series of halogen-rich volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes that plausibly linked the eruptions to the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation. This provides a unique link between the past and the present, and highlights the importance of stratospheric ozone depletion for climate.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also reveals that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the world’s poor and undernourished. However, the high dependence of poor and undernourished people on inland fisheries makes them vulnerable to threats to food security, such as habitat degradation and overfishing. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management of freshwater fisheries and to identify areas where fisheries can contribute to food security. This information is critical for protecting the benefits that rivers provide to billions of people.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. Aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The ability to regenerate is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate following injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery is made possible by a combination of genetic and molecular approaches, which have led to the identification of a previously unknown form of ectopic axon growth in the same neuron type. These findings are important for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. They also suggest that the mammalian CNS may be more regenerative than previously thought. Finally, our study provides a model for the development of regenerative medicine.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences, and it is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and species. In eukaryotes, recombination is also important for the generation of genetic variation in the course of evolution. The distribution of recombination across the genome is a key determinant of the genetic architecture of a species. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination in the genome of a flowering plant, and we show that the pattern of recombination is similar to that in yeast and in mice. These results provide insights into the evolution of recombination in eukaryotes.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a large number of brain regions. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of networks of brain regions that are functionally and anatomically connected. However, the number of networks is large, and it is not clear whether they are stable or change over time. Here, we show that the dominant network in healthy subjects is topologically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the networks in the brain during task performance. The dominant network was deactivated during task performance, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a new perspective on the resting brain and its functional organization. It also provides a new approach to the study of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is known to regulate translation. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes, which we call the NAD+ cap. We show that NAD+ cap-containing mRNAs are found in both the nucleus and mitochondria. We also show that NAD+ cap-containing mRNAs are produced cotranscriptionally. These results define a new class of 5′ cap structures in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that the NAD+ cap could regulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery is important for understanding the role of 5′ cap structures in the regulation of gene expression. It also has implications for the evolution of the 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes. The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) was a landmark study in the field of diabetes research. It showed that intensive therapy could prevent the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. However, the mechanisms behind this effect are not fully understood. Here we show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years after the DCCT, and that these differences are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a resource for future studies on the mechanisms behind metabolic memory. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a complex disease with a high prevalence and a high social and economic impact. The mechanisms underlying the development of this disorder are not fully understood. In this study, we show that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be involved in the development of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. These volatiles are produced during fruit ripening, and the biosynthetic pathways for many of them are not known. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the formation of the nitrogenous moiety. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. However, these threats are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the conservation and management of biodiversity and the maintenance of ecosystem services. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a large number of neurons that fire in a place-dependent manner, and the precise organization of these neurons is critical for understanding how the brain represents the location of objects and scenes in space. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that neurons that fire in a place-dependent manner are organized into distinct clusters, and that these clusters are anatomically distinct from clusters of neurons that fire in a head-direction-dependent manner. These results provide a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and will help us understand how the brain represents the location of objects and scenes in space. (Show more)

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they click. But how do we know when two people are connected? We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by others to judge the quality of the connection between two people, and it is used by the people themselves to judge the quality of their connection with others. This signal is so robust that it is used by people who have never met the other person before. This finding has implications for our understanding of social connection, as well as for the design of social technologies.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate, and their function is critical for maintaining normal heart rate. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in SANCs and plays a critical role in the regulation of SAN function. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate SAN function. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. Although the function of Si in plant physiology has been well established, its role in plant resistance against insect herbivory has been less clear. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances resistance against the rice leaffolder in rice plants, and that this effect is dependent on jasmonate (JA) signaling. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact in the plant defense response against insect herbivory. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome of macrophages. These findings may help to understand the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in the regulation of lipid metabolism in other cell types.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the adaptive changes in the firing rates of neurons. We show that these changes can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. Our results provide a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of gene delivery strategies for plants. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNAs to plants. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization. Nutrient inputs from small tributaries are often overlooked in efforts to reduce nutrient loading in large water bodies. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, especially in large water bodies where they are numerous. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This approach could be applied to other large water bodies, such as the Great Lakes, to help protect the ecological and economic values of these valuable resources.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is highly selective with respect to the chemical concentrations it can access. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems theory. Our results suggest that the saddle-node bifurcation may be a general feature of complex chemical systems, and that it may be responsible for the emergence of many of the observed properties of these systems.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the presence of NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain, leading to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes can be used to predict the onset of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in a mouse model of the disease. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the EEG spectrum may be a useful biomarker for the presence of NMDAR-Abs in patients with autoimmune encephalitis. This may help to guide treatment decisions. Finally, our findings highlight the importance of considering the effects of disease on the underlying microcircuitry when trying to understand the mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and it is important to understand the history of abrupt warming in the past. We present a study of a global warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma, during a glacial period. We show that the warming was accompanied by a global-scale perturbation of the carbon cycle, which is not observed in the greenhouse climate states of the modern Earth system. The warming was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and to a change in the structure of the ocean circulation. These results provide insights into the mechanisms that can lead to rapid warming of the Earth system. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the main tool used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. This study highlights the importance of certification in the palm oil sector and the need for certification to be more effective in reducing deforestation. This article is protected by copyright. The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 evolutionarily conserved subunits. The small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an organism is often a key factor in its biology and ecology. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In some species, multiple alleles at a single locus determine sex, and in others, the sex of an individual is determined by multiple loci. In this paper, we investigate the effects of multiple alleles on the secondary sexual characteristics of a species. We find that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by multiple alleles provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the maintenance of multiple alleles at a sex determination locus is a key factor in the evolution of sexual polymorphism. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of lipofuscin, a complex of autofluorescent bisretinoids and other species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. In albino mice treated with the Fe chelator deferiprone (DFP), intracellular Fe levels were reduced, and bisretinoid levels were reduced. Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that the evolution of siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, is a case study in morphological innovation and evolution. Our results show that siphonophore specialization is not a dead end, but rather a case of morphological evolution that has allowed for the diversification of predatory niches. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. This work also highlights the importance of studying the evolutionary history of predators to understand the diversity of their current ecological roles.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The fossil record of the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the origin of the derived features of the modern human hand is poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand from the Middle Pleistocene of East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the modern human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study also highlights the importance of the fossil record in understanding the evolution of the human hand. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways supporting cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which supports the synthesis of purine and thymidine. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key player in this pathway, and its inhibition is a promising strategy for cancer treatment. Here we report the discovery of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, and show that these compounds are effective in cancer cell lines. However, one-carbon donor formate is required for cellular SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a DLBCL cell line. This finding suggests that SHMT inhibition may be a promising strategy for DLBCL treatment. This work provides a proof-of-concept for the use of SHMT inhibition as a therapeutic strategy for DLBCL, and may lead to the development of a new class of targeted therapeutics for cancer and other diseases. The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by having access to natural landscapes such as forests. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the impact of deforestation on people’s diets. This is a relatively new area of research, and we hope that this study will encourage others to use this approach to understand the impact of deforestation on people’s diets and other aspects of their lives.

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanised system, with the weight of farm machinery now exceeding that of the largest land animals that walked Earth. This has led to the compaction of the soil, which is a key factor limiting the productivity of agricultural land. We show that the compaction of the subsoil has become a more widespread problem over the last century, and that it now threatens the productivity of 20% of arable land. This calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery, considering intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest land animals, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This study highlights the need for a better understanding of the ecological history of animals to inform the design of modern agricultural machinery.
